photo.title: Coffee Bridge

photo.description: This is a unique passage-way, over 1 km long, which connects Palazzo Vecchio to Palazzo Pitti, passing across the Arno above the Ponte Vecchio. It was commissioned from Giorgio Vasari, the architect of the Uffizi, by Cosimo I in 1565 to celebrate the marriage of his son Francesco and Joanna of Austria and was completed in only six months. This private corridor enabled the Medici to move freely between their private residence and the seat of government, without having to have an escort. The Vasari Corridor contains a selection of 17th and 18th-century paintings and the famous collection of Artists' self-portraits belonging to the Uffizi Gallery.
photo.tags: italy palazzovecchio uffizigallery arno river bridge pontevecchio giorgiovasari cosimoi medici florence vasaricorridor ponte firenze tuscany tuscana italia trip 2003 wildcard
photo.title: The Vasari Corridor

photo.title: Sunset Bridge

photo.description: This picture down the Arno from the Vasari Corridor on the Ponte Vecchio. This one section of the Corridor has large picture windows, rather than the small private ones. They were installed by Mussolini for Hitler's visit to the city. Because of the experience, Hitler countermanded his own order later in the war to blow up all the bridges spanning the Arno, sparing the Ponte Vecchio.

photo.title: Vasari Corridor

photo.title: Pisa is that way

photo.description: El mas conocido de los puentes de Florencia sobre el Arno. Construido originalmente por los romanos en madera fue reconstruido en piedra. Se puede ver en la parte superior el Corredor Vasariano que conecta el Palazzo Vecchio con el Palazzo Pitti. The most famous Florence bridge over the Arno. Built originally by Romans in wood it was rebuilt in stone. At top is possible to see the Vasari's Corridor that connects the Palazzo Vecchio with the Palazzo Pitti.
photo.tags: ponte vecchio puente italy toscana tuscany italia florence florencia lumix lx2 creativecommons cc
photo.title: Ponte Vecchio
